title: Fox in Steven Marshall's burning henhouse
text:
Remember that in 2015, Stead raised $9.1 million of Blue Sky investors’ cash to feed into Fox’s furnace. Oh, and $1.6 million in fees Blue Sky kept for itself. Despite promising that “all annual fees paid upfront will be refunded” if it exited the investment before 2020, Blue Sky tipped undrawn fund monies into a later bridge (read: desperation) funding round – by which point shrewder VC had turned off the taps. Its investors got no refund. Class act?

Shoes of Prey was just one of many unviable enterprises through which Stead set fire to other people’s money (OPM). There was the $11.5 million Blue Sky dusted on “hip cafeteria chain” Thr1ve, defunct social media platform Hey Let’s and the $25 million it poured into Vinomofo, whose own collision with reality is surely imminent. Her previous employer, CM Capital Investments, was liquidated in 2014.

“The thing that matters, and the only thing that will matter in the end, [is] whether I did the right thing, whether we took care of our shareholders or investors, and whether we were able to return capital to them in the way we hoped,” Stead told a start-up blog in November. “Were we good people and did we make good decisions?” Herein the answers: no, no, no, arguable and no.

Yet the South Australian government is now seeking a new manager of its SA Venture Capital Fund, its precondition being that the successful provider continues to employ Stead. Because continuity. It’s downright embarrassing, even by Adelaide’s basement-low standards. Premier Steven Marshall wants the world to know his long mendicant state is finally open for business. With this scandalous directive, he only leaves it open to ridicule.

With his taxpayers’ funds, what big idea will Stead co-invest in next? A prototype DVD rewinder? Or perhaps motorised ice-cream cones?

Marshall could be a national hero by paying Stead $1 million each year not to ‘invest’ OPM. In her case, it’s nothing ventured, nothing lost.
description: Shoes of Prey founder Jodie Fox exhibits about as much shame at losing other people's money as her Blue Sky buddy Elaine Stead. So none.
